carolinebramwell: Love the look and wishing you a speedy recovery. Once you're healed up you will be able to throw away the stick and do so much. I was a couch potato before my ileostomy surgery but now I compete in Ironman triathlons. No need for a seat on the train for me, I mix it up with the professionals in races. Having an ileostomy will show you what you CAN do, not what you Can't. I'm always happy to chat.
miss_emma_laverton: You're looking amazing! Nice to see someone young showing that walking sticks and other aids are nothing to be ashamed of at our age. My mum had arthritis and a hip replacement at the age at 25 and she was always too afraid of being judged for using a stick until she was past 50. Only now, at 57 has she started using one and regrets not doing it years ago 💗💗💗

inkyplum: I’m usually on crutches because of a chronic illness and often find people can be quite rude on the tube - even when the illness presents itself as being more obvious! Constantly have to ask for the priority seat and am often refused. Sometimes people are shits 🤦‍♀️
rosiiecampbell: hopefully you'll also be able to master the anticipation that people feel when they hear your walking stick tap it's way down the hall👏
florastreeter: You can apply for a ‘Please offer me a seat’ badge for the London Underground to show that you have a chronic/not necessarily visible issue. So that you don’t have to awkwardly ask or try and make it more obvious

grace.wxlmsley: You look so pretty!! Hope you’re feeling better 💛💛💛
shimmerandrotxo: Yas girl! I have one as a just in case, it’s nice to have the support there. 🧡
heather.lianne20: One of the most surprising thing you’ll find is that elderly people are actually the rudest people to you when you have a disability or something to help you get around. It’s quite disheartening really
alexc010: Have you signed up for one of those badges they give for the underground that says ‘offer me a seat please’ or something similar - it’s to help people with invisible illness ask for a seat without having to actually ask - might take some of the anxiety away
eszterkate: You look really badass! It's so awesome that there are options besides plain black to really make an accessory out of a walking stick. :D

_laura.kay_: Invisible illnesses suck so hard :( I had this trouble after I had brain surgery a couple of years ago, and I never had a stick or a pin to specify that I couldn’t stand up for very long without falling over. I hope your stick makes people less ignorant, love❤️

immywebb: Hi Hannah! In terms of getting a seat on the tube, if you want an extra “signaller” for people, you can order a (free) badge from TFL which says “please offer me a seat”.
